review.title: Learning a Representation of a Believable Virtual Character's Environment with an Imitation Algorithm
review.abstract: In video games, virtual characters' decision systems often use a simplified representation of the world. To increase both their autonomy and believability we want those characters to be able to learn this representation from human players. We propose to use a model called growing neural gas to learn by imitation the topology of the environment. The implementation of the model, the modifications and the parameters we used are detailed. Then, the quality of the learned representations and their evolution during the learning are studied using different measures. Improvements for the growing neural gas to give more information to the character's model are given in the conclusion.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 101 2.60 18v1 [cs.AI] 29 Dec 201 0In video games, virtual character decision systems often use a simplified representation of the world. In order to increase both their autonomy and credibility, we would like these characters to be able to learn this representation from human players. We propose to use a model called growing neural gas to learn the topology of the environment by imitating it. Implementation of the model, the modifications and parameters we use are detailed, and then the quality of the learned representations and their development during learning are examined using various metrics. Improvements for the growing neural gas to give the character model more information are set out in the conclusion.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: One of the main objectives of video games is to make the user feel that he / she really is in the game environment. To achieve this, it is possible to use complex devices to enhance immersion, such as surround sound systems and stereoscopic screens. Another possibility is to create rich environments to increase the presence, which can be achieved, among other things, by having characters with credible behaviors (Bates 1994). To generate these behaviors, artificial intelligence models are used in the game industry. In order for these models to perceive the environment, game designers need to create a simplified representation of the environment, which is often defined as prioritized. Manually determining the representation of each new environment is a time-consuming work. We suggest that our characters will be able to learn these representations in order to be autonomous. This learning will be unattended and online: the character will learn while playing, judging the person.

sections.heading: LEARNING A REPRESENTATION OF THE ENVIRONMENT
sections.text: The problem with the latter solutions is that they use algorithms to find the optimal path between two points and not the most credible path. With diagrams it is possible to have more control over the paths used by the characters. Instead of creating diagrams a priori, we want them to be learned by imitating a human player. This work than done in (Thurau et al. 2004) where nodes and a potential field are learned by people playing a video game. The character is then using this representation to move around the game environment, following the field defined at each node. To learn the position of the nodes, we use an algorithm called Growing Neural Gas (GNG).

sections.heading: IMPROVEMENTS
sections.text: The biggest difference between the GNG we implemented and the manually encoded navigation graphs is that the latter also provide information about the accessibility of one node from another. Edges in a GNG only give information about proximity, but there may be an obstacle between two nodes connected by an edge. An idea might be to store the previously enabled node and create an edge to the currently enabled node. Like the GNG edges, we should leave the edge channel age and disappear when it is too old. Whether these edges should replace the GNG edges could be an interesting experiment to share more information with the behavioral model, we can learn what kind of action is performed when the sign is near a node. The sign that knows its next node can select the best action to do.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: Virtual environments, such as video games, need credible characters so that the user can feel in the environment. In order to improve the behavior of the characters, we have decided to use a growing neural gas to learn by mimicking the topology of the environment. We believe that it will lead the agent to use the environment more humanely. It also takes the burden off the map designers to place the navigation graphics manually. Our initial evaluations tend to show that the growing neural gas provides a good representation of the environment. Learning is fast, with a demonstrator taking up to 25 minutes to learn a representation of the entire environment. As it is possible to learn with several demonstrators, learning can be done very quickly. Therefore, the character can quickly adapt to changes in the use of the environment and develop during game.Although different runs provide different results, the representations are very similiar.With this ability to learn the environment, the agent can be deactivated in any simulation without prior knowledge of the gas and can still move very quickly through the gas.
